Apple Pie Overnight Oats ğŸğŸ¥§â 
â 
Recipe by: @danica.dedicâ 
â 
Serves 4 - Per Serveâ 
457 calories - 25g protein - 15g fat - 54g carbsâ 
â 
INGREDIENTS:â 
- 275g Apple, Diced (aprox 2 apples)â 
- 25g Queenâ€™s Pure Canadian Maple Syrupâ 
- 1 Tsp Ground Cinnamonâ 
- 500ml Lite Milkâ 
- 5g Queens Natural Vanilla Extractâ 
- Pinch of Saltâ 
- 200g Rolled Oatsâ 
- 30g Vanilla VPA Whey Isolateâ 
- 1/2 Tsp Ground Cinnamonâ 
- 1/4 Tsp Ground Gingerâ 
- 1/8 Tsp Ground Nutmegâ 
- 15g Chia Seedsâ 
- 200g Chobani Natural Light Yoghurtâ 
- 40g Walnutsâ 
â 
METHOD:â 
Add diced apples to a pan with maple syrup and cinnamon over a medium heat. Once apples begin to sizzle, cover and cook for 5 minutes. Remove lid and cook for an extra 2-3 minutes, stirring occasionally.â 
â 
In a large bowl, add milk, vanilla extract and salt. Add 1/4 cup of apple mixture. Use a stick blender to mix and create apple flavoured milk. Add in oats, vanilla whey, cinnamon, ginger, nutmeg and chia seeds. Mix to combine and set aside for an hour to absorb.â 
â 
Divide mixture into 4 seperate glass jars/containers (I like to add some apple mixture half way). Top with greek yoghurt, remaining apples and walnuts. Refrigerate overnight. These will store in the fridge for up to 5 days in an air tight container.â 
â 
*If you donâ€™t have a stick blender use a normal blenderâ 
*Use rolled oats as better texture than quick oatsâ 
*Can remove protein powder if you donâ€™t want to utilise it - calories and macro will be alteredâ 
â 
#overnightoats #mealprep #breakfast #breakfastprep #highproteinbreakfast #breakfastrecipe

ğŸ“± Screen time: Limit screens before bed. Cutting out devices like iPads and smartphones before bedtime can promote better sleep quality.â

HOW TO STAY MOTIVATED THIS WINTER ğŸ’ªâ„ï¸â 
â 
In winter, our energy levels can take a hit as the days get shorter and colder. This disrupts our sleep and can make it tough to stay motivated. But staying active through exercise boosts our immune system, reducing the risk of winter blues and the flu. â 
â 
Here are some tips to keep you motivated: â¬‡ï¸â 
â 
ğŸ’ª Stay Active: Exercise helps boost your immune system and combat winter blues. Even a short workout can make a big difference!â 
â 
ğŸŒ Get Sunlight: Catching some rays can boost your mood by triggering the release of serotonin. Aim for just 10-15 minutes a day.â 
â 
ğŸ‘¯â€â™‚ï¸ Find a Partner: Team up with a friend or family member to keep each other motivated and on track with your goals.â 
â 
ğŸ“ˆ Track Your Progress: Celebrate your small victories and keep track of your accomplishments to stay motivated and focused on your goals.â 
â 
ğŸ’§ Stay Hydrated: Drinking plenty of water throughout the day can help fight fatigue and keep you energised. Try the electrolyte blend if you struggle drinking water alone. â 
â 
ğŸ³ Eat a Healthy Breakfast: Fuel your day with a nutritious breakfast to boost your energy levels and support your overall well-being. Mix up some whey protein with your oats, for a filling fibrous meal.â 
â 
Don't let winter slow you down! Stay active, stay motivated, and crush your goals this season! ğŸ’¥ â

ğŸ‹Lemon Blueberry Protein DoughnutsğŸ©
ğŸ¥: @danica.dedic

Makes 6
Per Serve
 - 95 calories 
- 8g protein 
- 14g carbs
 - 2g fat

INGREDIENTS
- 30g VPA Whey Isolate
- 20g White Wings Plain Flour
- 5g Natvia Natural Sweetener
- 5g Baking Powder
- 70g Chobani Light Natural Greek Yoghurt
- 70g Three Threes Apple Sauce
- 1 x Whole Egg
- 20g Lemon Juice
- 50g Blueberries

Icing:
- 30g CSR Icing Sugar
- 10g Lemon Juice

METHOD:

Preheat oven to 180 degrees.
In a bowl, mix whey, flour, sweetener and baking powder.
In a separate bowl, mix greek yoghurt, apple sauce, egg, and lemon juice.

Combine wet and dry ingredients and mix to combine. 

Divide into 6 doughnut holes on a doughnut tray (silicone trays work best - easiest to pop out) and top with blueberries.

Bake for 10-15 minutes until cooked through.

Remove from oven and allow to cool for 5 min.

Meanwhile, mix icing sugar and lemon juice. Remove the doughnuts from the tray and dunk into the icing mixture.

Enjoy ğŸ¤Œ

Another delish recipe from @eatingforfuelâ

If you love warm sweet treats, this recipe is for you! Itâ€™s easy to make and so delicious when served with cold ice cream to melt into the crumbly goodness ğŸ¤¤â 
â 
332 CALSâ 
31G PROTEINâ 
â 
Berry base:â

Method:â

Strawberry corn thin slice! ğŸ“âœ¨ â 
This easy treat recipe inspired by my girl @chloeevegan is gluten free, easy to make, no-bake, high in protein and can be turned vegan by swapping one ingredient!â 
â 
120 CALSâ 
7G PROTEINâ

By @josiesflexiblefoodsâ

ONLY 170 calories & over 11 grams of PROTEIN ğŸ¥¹ğŸ’•â 
â

INGREDIENTSâ 
Base:â

â

350g @yoproau Yogurtâ

2 x eggsâ

raspberriesâ

- Bake at 160 degrees for 30-40 mins, let cool then Refrigerate overnightâ 
- Cut into 12 slices & enjoyâ

Recipe by: @danica.dedicâ

Makes 4 servesâ

245 calories - 21g protein - 11g fat - 17g carbsï¿½ï¿½â

INGREDIENTS:â

METHOD:â

Looking to take your fitness and health to the next level? ğŸ˜â 
â 
Stack up your aminos! Amino acids are the building blocks of protein, and they're essential for muscle growth, repair, and recovery. ğŸ’ªâ 
â 
There are three amino acids that are particularly important for athletes and fitness enthusiasts: GABA, L-glutamine, and L-carnitine.â 
â 
1ï¸âƒ£ GABA is a calming amino acid that can help reduce stress and anxiety. It can also help improve sleep quality and boost athletic performance.â 
â 
2ï¸âƒ£ L-glutamine is an essential amino acid that helps support muscle growth and repair. It can also help boost the immune system and reduce muscle soreness.â 
â 
3ï¸âƒ£ L-carnitine is an amino acid that helps shuttle fat into the mitochondria, where it can be burned for energy. It can also help improve endurance and performance.â

LADIES! Have you put off adding Creatine to your supplement stack because you don't want to look 'bulky'? ğŸ’ªğŸ™â€â™€ï¸â 
â 
There is a stigma surrounding Creatine and that it is only a supplement that you take if you want to gain some serious muscle and strength ğŸ’ª You may have also heard that creatine causes water retention and weight gain.â 
â 
Whilst some of this is partially true, only a portion of the picture has been painted. â 
â 
Creatine is one of the most researched supplements in the marketplace and is a naturally occurring molecule within our bodies.â 
â 
Creatine increases the rate at which energy can be produced and used within our body. It helps you work harder and work longer by helping to replenish your energy systems. This increases peak power output, and this in turn has and this has several positive impacts on sports performance and body composition. For Women, this can mean gaining lean muscle mass (which may see the scales rise as muscle weighs more than fat). â

â 
Whilst some of this is partially true, only a portion of the picture has been painted. â 
â 
Creatine is one of the most researched supplements in the marketplace and is a naturally occurring molecule within our bodies.â 
â 
Creatine increases the rate at which energy can be produced and used within our body. It helps you work harder and work longer by helping to replenish your energy systems. This increases peak power output, and this in turn has and this has several positive impacts on sports performance and body composition. For Women, this can mean gaining lean muscle mass (which may see the scales rise as muscle weighs more than fat). â

ğŸ˜ BISCOFF PROTEIN CHEESECAKES ğŸ˜â 
â 
The goodness of biscoff and premium protein powder in cheesecake form, it can't get any better than this! This luscious Biscoff Protein Cheesecake recipe is perfect for any occasion, may it be birthdays or days where you feel like treating yourself. Made with VPA's WPI protein powder. ğŸ”¥â 
â 
NUTRITION:â 
Calories 277, Protein 22 grams, Fat 12 grams, Carbs 20 gramsâ 
â 
INGREDIENTS:â 
â 
3 x McVities Digestive Biscuitsâ 
20g Devondale 25% Less Fat Butter, Meltedâ 
200g Chobani 0.5% Fat Greek Yoghurtâ 
100g Philadelphia 60% Less Fat Cooking Cream Cheeseâ 
60g VPA Vanilla Whey Isolateâ 
20g Biscoff Smooth Spreadâ 
3g Gelatine Powderâ 
30g Boiling Waterâ 
2 x Biscoff Biscuitsâ 
10g Biscoff Smooth Spreadâ 
â 
DIRECTIONSâ 
ğŸ˜ 1. In a food processor or blender, blitz your biscuits until they become fine crumbs. Add in melted butter and mix until combined.â 
ğŸ˜ 2. Weigh your total base mixture and divide by 4, this will give you the total grams of biscuit base per cheesecake. Evenly distribute into 4 muffin holes in a silicone muffin tin (NOTE: It has to be silicone so that you can easily pop out the cheesecakes once set). Refrigerate.ğŸ˜3. To make the filling, mix together greek yogurt, cream cheese, and protein powder. In a small bowl, combine the gelatine powder with boiling water and mix until dissolved. Once dissolved, add to the cheesecake mixture and mix until well combined.â 
ğŸ˜ 4. Melt Biscoff spread and add to cheesecake mixture and mix until well combined.â 
ğŸ˜5. Weigh your total cheesecake mixture and divide by 4, this will give you the total grams per cheesecake. Distribute the mixture into muffin holes on top of the base. Refrigerate for at least 3 hours (overnight preferred). Once set, pop cheesecakes out of molds. Drizzle over melted Biscoff spread and crush Biscoff biscuits. Serve and enjoy.â 
â

Wet ingredients:â

Method:â

Easter is just around the corner! Check out this MINI EGG MILLIONAIREâ€™S SHORTBREAD SLICE by VPA Ambassador Rose @dietitianrose ğŸ°â 
â 
WHAT YOUâ€™LL NEED:â 
Base:â 
1 cup or 100g oat flourâ 
1 heaped scoop (35g) protein powder (I used @vpa_australia vanilla plant)â 
4 tbsp or 40mL maple syrupâ 
3 tbsp or 30mL macadamia oilâ 
1 tsp 3g vanilla extractâ 
â 
Middle:â 
100g peanut butter (I used @mayversfood smooth variety)â 
40ml maple syrupâ 
â 
Top:â 
~100g chocolate of choice, meltedâ 
@cadburyaust mini eggs (crushed & whole)â 
â 
METHOD:â 
1. In a small bowl combine the base ingredients until a dough-like consistency forms. Transfer mixture into a rectangular small baking dish (~9cmx5cm) and press down firmly. Set aside.â 
â 
2. Meanwhile prepare the filling by combining the above filling ingredients in a small bowl. Once smooth in consistency (& thickened), using a spatula, spread the middle layer out evenly on top of the base.â 
â 
3. Finally, melt the chocolate in a microwave safe bowl for ~1.5-2 minutes, or until melted (stopping every 30 seconds to stir to prevent chocolate from burning). Pour chocolate over the middle layer, and using the back of a spoon evenly distributed.â 
â 
4. To finish, place a few mini eggs on top, including some crushed ones.â 
â 
5. Freeze for ~2 hours or until set. Cut into desired bar/ square pieces (tip here: ensure the middle layer of the slice is set/ slightly frozen first before attempting to cut - if there is any â€œoozeâ€ of the peanut butter layer, itâ€™s not ready). Also ensure that you use a sharp knife! AND if you forget about it in the freezer like I did, donâ€™t sweat it! Just allow it to thaw for ~5-10 minutes before cutting ğŸ˜Šâ

Wise words from our VPA Ambassador of the month, @dietitianrose ğŸ‘‡ğŸ»â 
â 
"Although it may seem like a simple concept, youâ€™d be surprised how actually eating enough and eating more consistently can have such an impact.â 
â 
There could be a bunch of reasons as to why you may find yourself over-eating. But, this is one of the more common ones that we see in clinics. In many situations, youâ€™re not eating enough/ not eating inconsistently (either intentionally, aka severe restriction due to body image concerns, disordered eating/ an eating disorder, etc or un-intentionally).â 
â 
However, eating minimal throughout the day, in attempt to control your caloric intake or in fear of â€œoverdoing itâ€ or â€œbingingâ€ when the opportunity arises to eat, is not the answer to solve your cravings and hence binge eating behaviours. Particularly done by those who feel guilty with their food choices and tend to couple this with copious amounts of training as way to compensate for the influx of extra calories.â 
â 
Most often than not, this will result in the complete opposite, where binge-eating behaviours can occur, especially the later half of the day, if the first half has been severely restricted (aka the â€œbinge restrict cycleâ€).â 
â 
The solution is not to be more â€œstrictâ€, have more â€œself controlâ€, eat less through out the day (aka time restricted eating), or chose the lowest calorie food options to control your caloric intake, but instead, giving yourself permission to actually eat. Eating whole, nutrient dense foods to provide your body with the energy it needs to thrive & perform. And most importantly, ditching the all or nothing â€œdietâ€ mentality with nutrition. No goods are off limits or â€œgoodâ€ versus â€œbadâ€, you can enjoy those foods, often demonised by diet culture, such as chocolate/ ice-cream/[insert food here], and still be â€œhealthyâ€. Everything has its extremities - just remember the dose is the poisons. No diet is perfect!â 
â 
Letâ€™s shift this focus to fuelling yourself adequately to perform: for life in general as well as training ğŸ’ªğŸ¼"

"Salted Caramel Almond Protein Balls âœ¨â 
â 
These protein balls went off this week in the kitchen ğŸ’¥. Bec & I had so much fun making these energy bites we couldnâ€™t wait to share them with you! These balls are vegan, gluten-free, oil-free and made with only 7 ingredients. Made in 15 minutes you can quickly whip up a batch so you can have these energy bites all week long!â 
â 
Makes 18 ballsâ 
Prep time: 15 minutesâ 
96cals per serveâ 
C12g | F3.8g | P4gâ 
â 
You need:â 
â€¢ Â¼ cup flax seedsâ 
â€¢ Â¼ cup hemp seedsâ 
â€¢ Â½ GF rolled oatsâ 
â€¢ Â½ cup almonds, plus 2 tbs for rollingâ 
â€¢ 200g pitted dates, roughly choppedâ 
â€¢ 1 tsp vanillaâ 
â€¢ 3 tbs VPA Salted Caramel Plant Protein powder â 
â€¢ 2-3 tbs waterâ 
â 
How to:â 
1. Chop 2 tbs of almonds into small pieces (for rolling), set aside.â 
2. Add the flaxseeds to a high-speed blender and blitz until the seeds are a fine consistency (this allows for proper absorption of nutrients and makes them easier to digest).â 
3. Add all the remaining ingredients except the water and blitz until mixture is finely processed. Add water little bits at a time until a dough consistency is reached.â 
4. Roll into balls and place on a plate.â 
5. Place balls in the fridge for a least 30 minutes to set. Store these in the fridge.â 
Enjoy! ğŸ˜‹"

â 
â 
ğŸŒ± Focus on eating a wide variety of plant sources like fruits, vegetables, legumes, whole grains, and nuts and seeds in their whole form. â 
ğŸŒ± Instead of focusing on what you can't eat, focus on what you can eat - once you open your mind to the idea of including more plants into your diet you will start to notice all the different options available.â 
ğŸŒ± Be patient and give your body time to adjust to the changes - go low & slow. Just like we train our muscles we can also train our gut microbes to grow stronger.â 
ğŸŒ± Start by having one plant-based meal per day. Breakfast is an easy place to start with a big bowl of oatmeal topped with some fruit. Yummo! ğŸ˜‹â 
ğŸŒ± Have fun. This is an exciting journey as you explore new foods, flavours & textures. Get adventurous in the kitchen & try veganise your favourite meals like lentil pasta bolognese or chickpea curry. In not too long you will have some go-to recipes in your repertoire.â

Game Changing ARM Growth TIPS ğŸ’ªğŸ¼ by VPA Athlete, @vyncentchau_â 
â 
1ï¸âƒ£ - Compound Movementsâ 
â 
If youâ€™re a beginner youâ€™re probably thinking, what? Arenâ€™t most arm exercises isolation movements? Nope. You use your arms indirectly as a sub-muscle group in almost every compound movement from regressed to progressed exercises at its utmost basic forms such as the bench press (push-ups), barbell squat (bw squat), OHP, dips, pulldowns and the list continues.â 
â 
Focus on your compound movements to build overall muscle mass and accessorise with isolation exercises, not the other way around!â 
â 
2ï¸âƒ£ - Tracking Progress (or lack of)â 
â 
Youâ€™re probably not doing this? Track the weights, sets and reps of your workouts. Then try and progress week by week. Adding volume means making it harder than the week before, either through extra reps, increased intensity, extra sets or even switching up the tempo of the movement. If you want to progress in anything, you need to track. Period.â 
â 
3ï¸âƒ£ - Food (or lack of)â 
â 
If youâ€™re a beginner, youâ€™re most likely not eating enough to grow muscle mass. If youâ€™re a hard gainer, Iâ€™d suggest starting easy and eat regular meals. Start with 3 meals per day then add an extra meal or 50-100g of carbs to each meal in order to grow. Progressive overload applied into your nutrition. To build muscle, you need to eat!

Why do athletes need Magnesium?â 
â 
Magnesium is an important electrolyte and is essential for athletes. It is critical for nerve and muscle function and is essential for maintaining bone health. Magnesium also acts in all the soft tissues cells and enzyme systems. It is involved in blood pressure, immunity, energy and insulin metabolism. Ensuring sufficient magnesium helps with optimal recovery, oxygen uptake and energy production. A magnesium deficiency may result in muscle spasms, nerve twitches, cramping and fatigue.â 
â 
Read more on the blog.

What does creatine do?â 
â 
As a both health and sports supplement, creatine is one of the most well researched and evidence backed supplements. In simple terms creatine increases the rate at which energy can be produced and used within our body. â 
â 
Creatine helps you work harder and work longer by helping to replenish our energy systems. This increases peak power output, and this in turn has and this has several positive impacts on sports performance and body composition.â

CREAMIEST PROTEIN OATMEAL!! ğŸ¤¤ğŸ˜ğŸ˜â 
Recipe by @thiccmummapigâ 
â 
"Best texture of oatmeal I've ever had, and it's my first time making it! Super easy super quick!!"â 
â 
Oatmeal:â 
- 1/3 cup quick oats - 2/3-1 cup water (depending on what texture you like considering the protein will make it thicker)â 
- 1/2 scoop protein powder (any is fine! The most basic flavour is vanilla but I used the banana flavour from @vpa_australia, I always use this brand, but banana was the only flavour I had on hand)â 
â 
Toppings (can use anything really):â 
- a little bit of unsweetened almond milkâ 
- 1/2 serve almonds (chopped)â 
- 1/2-3/4 tablespoon Protein Peanut Butterâ 
- chia seedsâ 
- cinnamonâ 
- frozen blueberriesâ 
- 1/2 bananaâ 
â 
Microwave for 90 seconds and that's it!â 
â 
I never thought I'd be using quick oats ever (because of my bad relationship with food), but it seems like it was the better option for this meal in particular for the texture. Quick oats are particularly better if you need an energy boost too!

Protein Carrot Cake ğŸ¥•ğŸ°â 
From @lisa.whithamâ 
â 
Cake:â 
50g grated carrotâ 
25g @yoproau plain yoghurtâ 
12.5g @vpa_australia vanilla protein powderâ 
25g self raising flourâ 
1 eggâ 
20ml Queens sugar free maple syrupâ 
1 tsp baking powderâ 
1 tsp vanilla essenceâ 
2 tsp natviaâ 
Spray olive oilâ 
â 
Frosting:â 
15g YoPro plain yoghurtâ 
35g Lite cream cheeseâ 
1 tsp chopped walnutsâ 
â 
Cake:â 
1. Pre heat oven to 150 degrees (fan forced) and lightly spray with olive oil a 10cm springform tin.â 
2. Add the sweetener, egg, yoghurt, maple syrup and vanilla to a bowl. Whisk until combined.â 
3. Sift the self raising flour, protein powder and baking powder into the wet mixture. Stir to combine.â 
4. Pour evenly into the springform tin.â 
5. Bake at 150 degrees for approximately 20-25 minutes.â 
6. Let cool completely before adding frosting.â 
â 
Frosting:â 
1. Stir the yoghurt and cream cheese together.â 
2. Spread evenly over the top of the cake.â 
3. Sprinkle on walnuts.â 
.â 
ENJOY! Donâ€™t forget to tag me in your carrot cake creations ğŸ˜‹â 
.â

âœ¨HOW TO FIND MOTIVATIONâœ¨â£â 
â 
By @abbey.pt ğŸ™ŒğŸ¼â 
â£â 
"It can be extremely difficult trying to find your motivation. You may be stuck at home or frustrated with this whole situation right now and just not feeling it. Iâ€™m going to share with you some tips for how to stay motivated so you can continue smashing goalsâ£."â 
â£â 
ğŸ’—Visualise your goalsğŸ’—â£â 
Seeing your goals everyday of the week will give you a constant reminder of your â€˜WHYâ€™. You can put up your goals on your fridge, desk, phone lock screen or even in your car. It could include pictures to have an emotional connection to your goal as well as affirmations and intentions. E.g. Putting an intention on your fridge â€œI choose to eat healthy foodsâ€. â£â 
â£â 
â£â 
ğŸ’—Take Action & Donâ€™t Overthink ğŸ’—â£â 
The more action you take to continue your goals the more motivation that will come when you begin seeing progress. Donâ€™t overthink it, why should/shouldnâ€™t workout? Should I put my alarm on snooze? etc. Stop wasting time debating with yourself, overthinking creates excuses. Everyone has obstacles during their day, donâ€™t let it ruin your success. â£â 
â£â 
â£â 
ğŸ’—Create a Reward SystemğŸ’—â£â 
This could be internal or external. Internal could be the sense of accomplishment or achievement. On a piece of paper, write down how you want to feel after achieving your goal (e.g. more energy to play with kids, to not judge myself in the mirror) External can be rewards including having one chocolate for dessert only if you achieved your eating intentions for the day. It could be buying your new outfit in a different size because you achieved your fat loss goal. â£â 
â£â 
â£â 
ğŸ’—Change your mindset ğŸ’—â£â 
Create happiness in every situation, set the mood for your emotions and mental state. Practise gratitude, write down 3 things youâ€™re grateful for. What would it be like if I didnâ€™t have my job? My partner? Access to food? Even looking up YouTube videos, TED Talks and books - find that push. â£â 
â£â 
â£â

Our ambassador of the month is Leigh Holland-Keen!â 
You can find Leigh at @leigh.hollandkeen on Instagram.â 
â 
Leigh has been a Strongwoman competitor for 10 years now. And is in the process of rebuilding strength to return to the sport after giving birth to her first baby. â 
â 
She says, "I have always trained on my own, each house we live in (Partner serves in the ADF) I renovate the garage into my own gym. It makes it super easy with working shift work ( I work as a Registered Nurse) and I find it beneficial with having a new baby.  Being a new mum certainly comes with its challenges. Life changes as you know it and it can be difficult to incorporate fitness into your life. With multiple complications post birth, it has taken a little longer to return to strength training however since birth I started implementing core and pelvic floor exercises into my everyday routine. Walking every day helped me recover a little quicker. Majority of the time I wait for my baby to have a nap then I can quickly train, I try fit in training every second day but as a mum it can be super difficult!"â 
â 
Achievement she's most proud of! â 
â 
Last August, I travelled home to Scotland and became the first woman to be awarded a full lift of the famous Dinnie Stones (144.47kg and 188.02kg each!). The previous woman Dr Jan Todd was awarded a partial lift more than 40 years previously. It was an incredibly moment surrounded by some of the world's greatest stone lifters.â 
â 
â 
â

Ingredients:â

â£
BEET-500 is a pure powder made from concentrated beetroot juice with no preservatives or additives. The excitement around beetroot juice as the latest sports supplement comes from its high nitrate content. Nitrate is converted nitric oxide (NO) and acts as a vasodilator, opening blood vessels and allowing more blood and oxygen to be delivered to muscles. Happy Pretzel Day! 26th April. He is a tasty Protein Bar drizzled with dark chocolate and topped with Pretzels.â£
-â£
Ingredientsâ£
3 scoops VPA Vanilla Premium Plantâ£
30g Coconut Flourâ£
Pinch of saltâ£
1 tbsp. Sugar Free Maple Syrupâ£
70ml Almond Milkâ£
65g Natural Peanut Butterâ£
Topping-â£
25g 80% Dark Chocolate (or sugar free)â£
Pretzelsâ£
-â£
Methodâ£
In a food processer combine all bar ingredients.â£
Transfer to a loaf tin and firming press in.â£

The new word on the block at every gym, bootcamp or fitness class is fascia. So your most likely wondering what the %#*% is fascia?â£
-â£
Fascia is fibrous collagenous tissue, which are part of a body wide tensional force system. In simple terminology fascia is a fibrous net of connective tissue, which surrounds every cell in the body and is heavily interconnected with muscular function. If you removed everything out of the body apart from the fascia you would be able to see an outline of the entire body. Fascia is a mammoth matrix that runs from the tips of the toes to the top of the head and is involved in nearly every organ and structure in between.â£

Water makes up a significant proportion (45-70% this ranges between individuals) of a personâ€™s body mass and this water contains a sizeable amount of electrolytes. For example, adipose tissue has a low water content (10%) and lean tissue such as muscle a high water content (76%), so the total fraction of water in the body is determined largely by the total fat content*. The water within out bodies are not present as plain water, they contain a wide range of electrolytes and solutes, they are dissolved in varying concentration in body fluids. The major cations (these are the positively charged electrolytes) in the body are sodium, potassium, calcium and magnesium; the major anions (the negatively charged electrolytes) are chloride and bicarbonate.â£

0THE FOUNTAIN OF YOUTH!â£
Collagen is often referred to as the bodyâ€™s scaffolding, as it is the protein that glues the body together and one of the most abundant proteins found in the human body.â€œItâ€™s the glue that holds the body together,â€ says New York dermatologist Whitney Bowe, author of The Beauty of Dirty Skin: The Surprising Science of Looking and Feeling Radiant from the Inside Out.â£
-â£
Whitney says that collagen supplies the volume that keeps your skin looking plump and prevents ageing lines. Itâ€™s also very high in the important amino acids proline and glycine, which work to repair your tendons, bones, and joints, extremely important for athletes and as you grow older. â€œAs we get older, we break it down faster than we can replace it,â€ she says. Whitney Bowe learned only a few years ago that people were now eating collagen instead of injecting it to make their skin look younger, and she was sceptical. But she has since changed her mind after seeing the science and her clientâ€™s results.â€œJust in the last few years, there have been some impressive studies showing that ingestible collagen can indeed impact the appearance of skin,â€ says Bowe. In 2014 a study of 69 women ages 35 to 55 revealed that those women who consumed only 2.5 or 5 grams of collagen every day for 8 weeks showed a huge improvement in their skin elasticity, compared with those who did not consume the collagen. Another study confirmed this result and found that women who took 1 gram of collagen per day for 12 weeks had 76% less dryness, 12% fewer visible wrinkles and better blood flow in the skin.â£

Do you know the performance benefits of BEET-500?â£
-â£
BEET-500 is a pure powder made from concentrated beetroot juice with no preservatives or additives, scientifically shown to improve athletic performance. The excitement around beetroot juice as the latest sports supplement comes from its high nitrate content. Nitrate is converted nitric oxide (NO) and acts as a vasodilator, opening blood vessels and allowing more blood and oxygen to be delivered to muscles. Nitrate may also reduce the energy cost of exercise and positively affect muscle contraction.â£
-â£
As a classified 'Class A' supplement (Australian Institute of Sport) BEET-500 has been found to have beneficial effects on performance for a range of endurance athletes due to its ability to promote blood flow and nutrient delivery. Bodybuilding and weight lifting athletes also find benefits from BEET-500 from its ability to promote muscle pumps. It also appears that athletes training or competing at altitude (a low oxygen environment) may have particularly good responses to BEET-500 (nitrate supplementation).â£

The recent excitement around beetroot juice as the latest sport supplement comes from its high nitrate content. Nitrate is converted to nitric oxide (NO) which acts as a vasodilator, opening blood vessels and allowing more blood and oxygen to be delivered to muscles. Nitrate may also reduce the energy cost of exercise and positively effect muscle contraction.â£
-â£
What is Nitrate?â£
Nitrate is actually found in many vegetables, but the recent hype around beetroot juice is because of its particularly high content of nitrate. Yes, beetroot juice can be made at home with your favourite blender or juicer but you can get the best results from using a concentrated dose which is also much easier to consume for the same amount of nitrate (70ml vs. ~500ml respectively).â£

â€œUse it or lose itâ€ vs muscle memory, what happens to our muscle if we stop resistance training? Now exercise physiologists do agree that muscle memory is real, but the question is how are these â€˜muscle memoriesâ€™ stored when our muscles seem to shrink with inactivity?â£
-â£
According to a scientific review published in Frontiers in Physiology found that although our muscle cells shrink due to disuse, the nuclei gained during resistance training remains. Meaning that when we are young we are able to store muscle nuclei to prevent fragility in old age, but it also means that steroid use in competitive sport has long term benefits years after the crime was committed.â£

What is BEET-500?â£
-â£
BEET-500 is a pure powder made from concentrated beetroot juice with no preservatives or additives, scientifically shown to improve athletic performance. The excitement around beetroot juice as the latest sports supplement comes from its high nitrate content. Nitrate is converted nitric oxide (NO) and acts as a vasodilator, opening blood vessels and allowing more blood and oxygen to be delivered to muscles. Nitrate may also reduce the energy cost of exercise and positively affect muscle contraction.â£
-â£
As a classified 'Class A' supplement (Australian Institute of Sport) BEET-500 has been found to have beneficial effects on performance for a range of endurance athletes due to its ability to promote blood flow and nutrient delivery. Bodybuilding and weight lifting athletes also find benefits from BEET-500 from its ability to promote muscle pumps. It also appears that athletes training or competing at altitude (a low oxygen environment) may have particularly good responses to BEET-500 (nitrate supplementation).â£
-â£

New research to be published in the March issue of Obesity reveals that the best predictor of weight-loss success is diet self-monitoring. Another amazing post from one of our favouite VPA strength athletes @itsjustloulouâ£
-â£
"Every day I am thankful I took responsibility for myself because I CHOSE. â£
I chose to love myself rather than wallow in self pity and anger. â£
I chose my physical health over drinking to excess. â£
I chose my mental health over drugs to numb it. â£
I chose my life over wanting death. â£
I chose strength in every single way. â£
I chose to take the pain of healing rather than numb it. â£
I chose to remove everything and everyone toxic from my life.â£
I chose to stop accepting invitations to people's drama. â£
I chose isolation so that I could heal and come back a better friend, a better partner and better mother. â£
I chose to take charge. â£
These things didn't just happen. â£
It took a lot of work. It wasn't comfortable, it was hard and the hardest part was admitting that I was the only one who could do something about it. The hardest part was to stop blaming everything else and start doing the work. â£
I look at where I am now, where my goals are leading me and I look at where I've come from and I'm infinitely proud of what I've achieved. â£
No one is going to save you. Start with taking just one step towards a better life and continue to take one small step a day..... One day you'll look back at how far you've come. It's worth the struggle. â£
These days I'm only interested in creating the life I deserve and the person my loved ones deserve. "â£
-â£

But the danger of being so hungry and overly optimistic because of your endorphins may cause you to make a poor decision and ruin all of your hard work.â£

According to a new study from the University of Nebraska-Lincoln,  the time when you decide what youâ€™re going to eat after a workout can dictate what you will eat and potentially undo all of your workout gains. This Tropical Cheesecake is a great twist on the classic baked cheesecake. The cheesecake layer is beautifully flavoured with Banana protein and topped with a delicious Mango/Passionfruit flavoured BCAA's Jelly.â£
-â£

-â£

-â£
Topâ£

500ml Waterâ£

Methodâ£

Why you should be using creatineâ€¦Well, first of 
all creatine is one of the most studied supplements with more positive reviews than negative from research experience. Second, it is on the cheaper end of the spectrum when it comes to what supplements are available on the market. Third, is also not too much of a hassle to consume since the powder, the form which it is usually consumed, mixes well with several liquids and has almost no flavour.
-
THE SCIENCE
Creatine is a nitrogenous organic acid that occurs naturally in vertebrate and helps supply energy to all cells in the body, primarily muscle. Under quick bursts of force the supplement has been studied to act in a certain way; â€œCreatine has the ability to increase muscle stores of PCr, potentially increasing the muscleâ€™s ability to resynthesize ATP from ADP to meet increased energy demandsâ€.
-
In short, analysis has found that creatine treatment increased muscle strength and potentially improved functional performance. Feel free to research further as there is a large amount of information available on the internet regarding this topic.
-
Creatine Monohydrate is proven to increase physical performance in successive bursts of short-term, high-intensity exercise. This has obvious benefits for anyone participating in exercise â€“ from bodybuilders and powerlifters to AFL and rugby players; who are all continually performing short bursts of intensive exercise. Creatine Monohydrate is the most widely researched sports supplement in existence.
-

A great post by Nutrition & Exercise Scientist @tyarranelson ğŸ¤˜
-
"A common misconception is that you build muscle in the gym... whereas you actually break it down.
-
When we work out, the repetitive motions of lifting heavy loads result in minute muscle tears and acute muscle catabolism (breakdown). However, this is a GOOD THING, because itâ€™s a physiological signal for our muscles to GROW. Following your workout, your muscles are incredibly sensitive nutrient uptake (particularly the amino acids from protein and glucose from carbohydrates). Itâ€™s these nutrients (in conjunction with sleep, a balanced diet with sufficient energy, adequate hydration and decreased stress) that help you RECOVER in the hours and days following your workout. These factors combined allow your muscles to repair, so they can grow to be bigger and stronger!
-
Remember, exercise is simply the stimulus. Itâ€™s adequate nutrition + recovery methods that ultimately change your body composition.
-
The current literature supports the notion of consuming ~25 grams of HBV protein 1-2 hours before and after your workout, to prime your muscles for growth and kickstart the recovery process. While this can be achieved by consuming any complete protein source, whey protein is an affordable, nutritious, convenient and palatable option. Give these 5 tips a try for developing your biceps ğŸ’ª
-
1. Don't Work Biceps After Back
Your biceps will already be fatigued and you won't get the most out of them. Instead, try training them after chest. - 
2. Use include dumbbell curls
Again and again, science has shown that incline dumbbell curls are one of the best exercises for bicep growth because of the full range of motion and constant tension applied to the long head of the bicep. -
3. Make Sure Your Back Training Is Intense
Studies have shown a lat pulldown can work your biceps as much as curls do, so hit back hard.
-
4. Ease up on the EZ Bar
If your wrists allow, start doing straight bar curls instead of the popular EZ bar curls, they are great for building your biceps.
-
5. Fix your wrist
Similar to how the straight bar can greatly benefit your biceps because of your wrist position, be conscious of your wrist position during dumbbell curls. -

Here is a great Gluten free loaf, loaded with delicious choc chips and packed with protein. I thoroughly enjoy this loaf as a second breakfast toasted or as a sweet 3pm pick me up. This recipes is already very low in carbs with just 9g per serve, but for those following a Keto diet it can be easily adapted by swapping the almond milk for heavy cream and part of the apple sauce for butter.
-
For my Vegan friends, see the ingredients list for simple vegan alternatives.
-
-
Ingredients 
3 scoops VPA Vanilla WPI (or VPA Premium Plant Vanilla)
3 cups Almond Flour
2 tbsp Coconut Flour
2 Chia Eggs
1 cup Apple Sauce
3/4 cup Almond Milk
1/3 cup Coconut Sugar
1 tbsp Baking Powder
2 tsp Vanilla
1/2 cup Dark Chocolate Chips (or Vegan Chocolate)
-
-
Method 
Preheat the oven to 180Âº. Grease and line a loaf tin.
In a large mixing bowl combine all ingredients, saving half of the choc chips.
Transfer the mixture to the loaf tin and sprinkle remaining choc chips over the top.
Bake for 40 minutes and enjoy while still warm, lathered in peanut butter. yum!
-
MACROS (per serve)
Cals: 236
Protein: 12.4g
Fat: 16.0g
Carbs: 9.2g

A great post explaining how caffeine and pre-workouts really work by @tyarranelson ğŸ’ª
-
"Iâ€™m not entirely sure just how much caffeine has flown through my veins... but I do know that I LOVE @vpa_australia pre-workout ğŸ˜›ğŸ’ª
-
As you may be aware, caffeine is the main ingredient in most pre-workout products ğŸ’Š However, caffeine does a whole lot more than just make you â€œfeel goodâ€ âš¡ï¸ In fact, caffeine is one of the most well-researched and powerful ergogenic aids (which means performance enhancing) supplements in the world.
-
Now, have you ever wondered what it is about caffeine that makes you feel more awake and perky? To understand we first need to clarify what makes us feel sleepy. As a result of daily activity a molecular bi-product called "adenosine" builds up in our system, which inhibits physiological processes and neurotransmitters associated with wakefulness, such as noradrenaline and serotonin. Caffeine is a central nervous system stimulant and is remarkably similar in molecular structure to adenosine. Caffeine can therefore bind to adenosine receptors in the brain and block their activity, which results in a higher level of alertness, concentration and energy expenditure.
-
Caffeine has been shown to enhance exercise performance with a dose of 3-6mg/kg of body weight consumed 1 hour before training. Caffeine can improve blood circulation, increase oxygen and nutrient delivery to your muscles, and can assist in higher levels of glycogen storage. This combination of factors can ultimately lead to greater power output, less perceived exertion and improved endurance during exercise!
-
Soo... if youâ€™re looking for a top-quality pre-workout supplement which can improve your exercise performance, sustain your energy levels and doesnâ€™t leave you feeling â€œcrashedâ€, I would highly recommend checking out @vpa_australia ! "

Are you strapped for time in the mornings or simply love to sleep in before rushing out the door and skipping breakfast? Make these Healthy Breakfast Muffins ahead of time and youâ€™ll never what to skip breakfast again.  Or if you are like me and enjoy training fasted in the morning, these are great breakfast on the go between gym and work. INGREDIENTS:
â— 2 cups Oat Flour
â— Â½ cup Coconut Sugar
â— 1 tbsp Baking Powder
â— 1 tbsp Cinnamon
â— 1 cup Milk
â— 1 Egg
â— 1 tsp Vanilla

Frosting

Healthy Chocolate Cherry Cake Recipe ğŸ˜
-
Cherry season is here and in full swing! (in Aus) And with Chocolate Cake Day just around the corner on 27th January, what better way to celebrate than with a Choc Cherry Cake. This quick and easy cake is deliciously moist and packed with more than 13g of protein per serve. Without flour this cake has less than 5g of carbs per serve making this the perfect dessert (or breakfast, no judgment here) for those on a low carb or keto diet. -
Ingredients:
o 2 cups Pumpkin (Steamed) 
o 1 cup Almond Butter (Natural) 
o Â½ cup Cocoa or Cacao 
o 2 scoops VPA Choc Cherry WPI -
Frosting- 
o 2 scoops VPA Choc Cherry WPI 
o 1-2 tbsp Stevia 
o 1-2 tbsp Almond Butter 
o Dash Milk -
Optional- 
Top with Cherries -
Method:
1. Steam the pumpkin until cooked through and blend in a food processer until smooth. 
2. Preheat oven to 180Âº and line a 20x20 square tin. 
3. Transfer pumpkin to a large mixing bowl and remaining cake ingredients. Mix until combined. 
4. Pour into cake tin and bake for 20-25 minutes. 
5. Combine frosting ingredients in a food processer, slowly adding the milk until thick but spreadable consistency. Allow cake to cool before frosting. 
6. Frost and top with Cherries. Keep refrigerated. -
MACROS (Per serve)
Serving size - 52.4g
Protein - 13.2g
Carbs - 4.3g
Fats - 9.4g
Cals - 168

Ingredients for Spiced Crispy Treats

PEANUT BUTTER PROTEIN COOKIES ğŸ˜‹ The perfect mid-week healthy treat!
-
1 cup peanut butter 
2/3 coconut sugar
2 scoops VPA Premium Whey vanilla
2 eggs
-
Instructions:
Pre-heat over to 180 degrees
Line baking tray with paper.
Combine all ingredients and mix until consistency resembles cookie dough. (Texture may vary depending on the peanut butter used).
If it looks too dry, add more peanut butter, if its too liquidy add more protein powder).
Scoop 2 tbs worth of batter and roll with hands. May need to wet hands with a few drops of water to keep the batter from sticking. 
Repeat with remaining dough, place them on the tray.  Use fork, press down gently on each cookie to create criss-cross marks.  If the fork sticks dip it in water as necessary. 
Transfer to oven and bake for 10-12 minutes, or until the edges of the cookies slightly start to turn brown.

Protein! Oh how I love thee. Start your weekend with these tasty treats!!!
-
PROTEIN CREPE RECIPE - 2 INGREDIENTS ONLY! -
INGREDIENTS:
1/2 cup Egg whites (roughly from 3 eggs)
1 scoop VPA Protein powder (all flavours work well)
Some fruit inside optional but recommended! -
METHOD:
Place a non-stick skillet over medium-high heat. In a bowl combine egg whites and protein powder and whisk until protein powder is COMPLETELY dissolved and lump free. 
Scoop about 1/3 of the mixture if using a small pan, into the pan and rotate pan around so the batter spreads thin. Cook until the bottom is lightly browned and flip it over to cook through.
-
DISCLAIMER: These should be eaten immediately after making them!  They are so tasty while fresh but let them sit out for 5 minutes and they get progressively drier and harder.  Don't say I didn't warn you!

Great post from one of our VPA Powerlifting Athletes @the_barbell_brat ğŸ’ª
-
"It's the time of year many people will make resolutions to change and a lot of those resolutions often revolve around becoming healthier which is great! 
With all the talk of body image and body positivity I want you to promise me something......
Start your journey from a place of love not hate for your body.
It is entirely possible to love your body and still want to change it. love how it moves, love how it progresses, love how it strengthens over the next year, love how capable you become, love how much faster you are, love that you look uniquely like you! Every scar, every dimple.
Take a holistic approach to the way you view "healthier" by reminding yourself that health includes mental health and that good mental health will only strengthen your ability to achieve good physical health. 
If you start from a place of love you cannot fail. To love yourself means you've already won in your journey to a healthier you. 
What is your new year's resolution?"
-

How to make Apple Pie Sliceâ €
1. Preheat the oven to 180Âº.â €

Keep on track this Christmas with these delicious vegan Gingerbread Cookies, packed with protein and lower in calories. These little guys are sure to be a hit not just with the health conscious but anyone with a sweet tooth. If you like your Gingerbread with a bit more heat add another teaspoon (or two) of ginger. These are a great vegan-friendly cookie that can be decorated in the traditional way or go crazy with everyone's favourite, smarty buttons. You could even make a double batch (double because half probably won't make it to the cooling rack), pop a few in a tin and gift them to friends or family. â €

Ingredients for Gingerbread Cookies:â €
2 cup Spelt Flourâ €

2 tsp Ginger (ground)â €
2 tsp Cinnamonâ €
Â½ tsp Baking Powderâ €
Â½ tsp Baking sodaâ €
Â½ tsp Cloves â €
Â½ tsp Nutmegâ €
Â½ tsp Saltâ €
Â½ cup Coconut Sugarâ €

-â €
How to make Gingerbread Cookies:â €
Preheat the oven to 170Âº and line a tray with greased baking paper.â €
In a large mixing bowl add all ingredients and mix until well combined.â €
Roll out the dough between 2 sliced or baking paper, approximately 5mm thick.â €
Using a cookie cutter press out your cookies and transfer to baking tray.â €
Chill in freezer for 10 minutes before baking for 10 - 12 minutes. â €

HEALTHY WHITE CHRISTMAS RECIPEâ €
-â €

Is it even Christmas day without White Christmas slice. I really enjoyed this slice as a child, blissfully unaware of hidden nasties I was consuming by the fist full (a slice in each hand, like every other kid). From copha to white chocolate and glazed cherries. â €
Ditch these highly processed ingredients and give this healthier version a go. â €
-â €
Ingredients for White Christmas â €
1 cup Coconutâ €
1 cup Cashewsâ €
Â¼ cup Coconut Milkâ €
Â¼ cup Coconut Oilâ €
1 tbsp Maple Syrup â €
1 tsp Vanillaâ €
3 scoops VPA Vanilla WPIâ €
70g Pistachios â €
50g Cranberriesâ €
-â €
How to make White Christmas â €
1. In a food processor blitz the Cashews and Coconut until super smooth.â €
2. Add the wet ingredients and Protein and mix until combined. â €
3. Transfer the mixture to a large bowl.â €
4. Roughly chop the pistachios and cranberries if you prefer them in small bits. â €
5. Add the pistachios and cranberries to the mixture.â €
6. Transfer and press into a lined loaf tin. â €
7. Set in the freezer for an hour or so and cut into bite-size squares. â €

A great post for the girls from one of our amazing VPA Athletes @jmac.attackâ €
-â €
â€œMENSTRUAL CYCLE PERIODIZATIONâ€ ğŸ’–ğŸ’â €
.â €
Does your menstrual cycle affect your strength, endurance, and susceptibility to injury when training? You betcha, girlfriend. ğŸ™‹ğŸ¼â€â™€ï¸â €
.â €
While Iâ€™ve been researching, applying, asking questions, testing, measuring and creating content for my new â€œ12 Week Womenâ€™s Only Training Programâ€ (to be released 2019), I have learnt SO MUCH about the female body, hormones, and training during different phases of your cycles! ğŸ’•â €
.â €
I certainly donâ€™t claim to be a doctor, gynecologist, or even an â€œexpertâ€ in this field, but being based as a Female-Specific trainer with bornformorefitness, understanding how to train my clients (and myself) EVEN better just increases my interest to learn and apply more and more of this helpful information. ğŸ¤“â €
.â €
In a world full of information (most very easily accessible/a little overwhelming), here are some quick facts about female-specific training that might help you along your journey: ğŸ’ªğŸ½ğŸ’ªğŸ½â €
.â €
ğŸŒ¸ We women tend to be stronger in the Follicular phase of our cycle (two weeks following your time of the month) when the estradiol to progesterone ratio is high (hamstrings are stronger by 11%).â €
ğŸŒ¸ Whether your goal is to improve strength, burn fat, gain lean muscle, the Follicular phase is the prime time for progression and maximal output.â €
ğŸŒ¸ Insulin sensitivity is higher during your Follicular phase, which means your body will be more prone to using carbs to fuel muscle gains. ğŸ˜â €
ğŸŒ¸ During ovulation, high estrogen levels can make women more susceptible to injury (single leg work, plyometrics, and glute/hamstring strengthening are best during this time).â €
ğŸŒ¸ During the Luteal phase of your cycle (two weeks leading up to your time of the month), your body will rely more on fat as a fuel source."â €

Whatâ€™s better than raisin toast? A home-baked fruit and nut bread with scattered chocolate coated goji berries. There is nothing quite like the smell of freshly baked bread, except for maybe fresh bread slathered with butter.â €
And thanks to Nodo this recipe is gluten-free. The Nodo Self Raising Flour has kept this bread perfectly moist,  making it hard to believe itâ€™s even gluten-free. â €

Ingredients for Fruit & Nut Bread:â €
2 Bananasâ €
4 Eggsâ €
90g Coconut Oilâ €
425g Nodo SR Flourâ €
200g Dried Fruit (Apricots, Figs, Dates)â €
210g Nuts (Macadamias, Hazelnuts, Pecans,)â €
2 scoops VPA Vanilla WPIâ €
Pinch of Saltâ €
2 tsp Baking Powderâ €
100g Chocolate Coated Goji Berries â €
-â €
How to make Fruit & Nut Bread:â €
Soak the dried fruit in boiling water for 15 minutes. â €
Preheat the oven to 150Âº and line a bread tin with greased baking paper. (tip- leave an inch of paper either side to help lift the bread out.)â €
Roughly chop nuts and drained fruit.â €
Mash banana in a large mixing bowl. Add all ingredients and mix until combined.â €
Transfer mixture to the loaf tin and bake for 50 minutes.â €

Keep on track this Christmas with these delicious vegan Gingerbread Cookies, packed with protein and lower in calories. These little guys are sure to be a hit not just with the health conscious but anyone with a sweet tooth. If you like your Gingerbread with a bit more heat add another teaspoon (or two) of ginger. These are a great vegan-friendly cookie that can be decorated in the traditional way or go crazy with everyone's favourite, smarty buttons. You could even make a double batch (double because half probably won't make it to the cooling rack), pop a few in a tin and gift them to friends or family. â €
-â €
Share your baking success with us on Instagram by tagging us at @vpa_australia â €
-â €
Ingredients for Gingerbread Cookies:â €
2 cup Spelt Flourâ €
2 scoops VPA Premium Plant Vanilla (SEE LINK BELOW)â €
2 tsp Ginger (ground)â €
2 tsp Cinnamonâ €
Â½ tsp Baking Powderâ €
Â½ tsp Baking sodaâ €
Â½ tsp Cloves â €
Â½ tsp Nutmegâ €
Â½ tsp Saltâ €
Â½ cup Coconut Sugarâ €
5 tbsp Coconut Oilâ €
3 tbsp Molassesâ €
Â¼ cup Apple Sauceâ €
2 tbsp Almond Milkâ €
-â €
How to make Gingerbread Cookies:â €
Preheat the oven to 170Âº and line a tray with greased baking paper.â €
In a large mixing bowl add all ingredients and mix until well combined.â €
Roll out the dough between 2 sliced or baking paper, approximately 5mm thick.â €
Using a cookie cutter press out your cookies and transfer to baking tray.â €
Chill in freezer for 10 minutes before baking for 10 - 12 minutes. â €

Start your morning with this tasty and healthy chocolate banana overnight oats ğŸ˜
-
Don't let a busy morning lead a healthy diet astray! 
Prepare this the night before and it's ready to be enjoyed straight out of the fridge!
-
INGREDIENTS:
1 banana, cut in half
1 cup old fashioned oats (not instant)
1 1/2 cups unsweetened almond milk
4 tbsp VPA WPI creamy choc Whey Isolate protein
1/2 tbsp chia seeds
-
DIRECTIONS: Cut one half of banana in slices and mash the other half. Add mashed banana, oats, almond milk, protein powder and chia seeds into a bowl.  Stir well to combine, until all the protein powder has dissolved.  Seal container with a lid and place in fridge overnight.  Take container out of the fridge next morning, stir the mixture. 
Add more milk if you feel its too thick, portion into two mason jars or bowls and then top away!  I added banana slices, cacao nibs, pomegranate arils and activated buckinis for some extra crunch! -
ENJOY!
-
@elleshungry
-
@vpa_australia

Who doesn't love Saturday Brunch! Now you can have the tastiest weekend brunch without blowing out your diet for the whole week with these tasty Blueberry Ricotta Protein Pancakes ğŸ˜
-
Delicately light and fluffy blueberry pancakes that melt in your mouth with a delicious sweetness and a hit of juicy blueberries!
-
INGREDIENTS: 
2 eggs
1 x 250g smooth ricotta
1 cup milk (i use almond but normal milk is fine)
1 cup self-raising flour
1 scoop VPA Protein Powder Vanilla
2 tsp baking powder
Pinch of salt 
1/4 blueberries for mix -
METHOD:
Whisk together the eggs, ricotta, milk until well combined and smooth.
Sift flour on top along with protein powder, baking powder and then mix until just combined.  Don't over beat the batter.  It will be thicker than normal, then gently fold in blueberries.  Heat non-stick pan over low-med heat and fry until golden brown, flip and cook remaining batter to make all pancakes. 
Serve with extra blueberries, [some fresh, some frozen (microwaved)], blackberries and walnuts! Maple syrup or honey over the top for some drippin' flavour!
-
THEN SMASH EM' - eat up!

THE PERFECT SUNDAY MORNING - HEALTHY BLUEBERRY RICOTTA PROTEIN PANCAKES
-
Delicately light and fluffy blueberry pancakes that melt in your mouth with a delicious sweetness and a hit of juicy blueberries!
-INGREDIENTS: 
2 eggs
1 x 250g smooth ricotta
1 cup milk (i use almond but normal milk is fine)
1 cup self-raising flour
1 scoop VPA Protein Powder Vanilla
2 tsp baking powder
Pinch of salt 
1/4 blueberries for mix -
METHOD:
Whisk together the eggs, ricotta, milk until well combined and smooth.
Sift flour on top along with protein powder, baking powder and then mix until just combined.  Don't over beat the batter.  It will be thicker than normal, then gently fold in blueberries.  Heat non-stick pan over low-med heat and fry until golden brown, flip and cook remaining batter to make all pancakes. 
Serve with extra blueberries, [some fresh, some frozen (microwaved)], blackberries and walnuts! Maple syrup or honey over the top for some drippin' flavour!
-
THEN SMASH EM' - eat up!
-

PEANUT BUTTER PROTEIN COOKIES ğŸ˜‹ Get your treat fix while keeping it lean!
-
1 cup peanut butter 
2/3 coconut sugar
2 scoops VPA Premium Whey vanilla
2 eggs
-
Instructions:
Pre-heat over to 180 degrees
Line baking tray with paper.
Combine all ingredients and mix until consistency resembles cookie dough. (Texture may vary depending on the peanut butter used).
If it looks too dry, add more peanut butter, if its too liquidy add more protein powder).
Scoop 2 tbs worth of batter and roll with hands. May need to wet hands with a few drops of water to keep batter from sticking. 
Repeat with remaining dough, place them on the tray. Use fork, press down gently on each cookie to create criss-cross marks. If the fork sticks dip it in water as necessary. 
Transfer to oven and bake for 10-12 minutes, or until the edges of the cookies slightly start to turn brown.

TIM TAM & CHIA SEED PROTEIN PANCAKES
-
INGREDIENTS:
2 cups SR Flour
1/4 tsp bi-carb soda
1/2 tsp caster sugar
1/2 tsp chia seeds
1 scoop VPA protein powder (any flavour tastes amazing!)
4 Tim Tams (2 crushed to fine crumb, other two just crushed for topping)
1.5 cups milk
1 egg
1 tsp vanilla extract 
a handful of rasberries
-
MIX DRY INGREDIENTS TOGETHER flour, bi-carb soda, sugar, chia seeds, protein powder and two finely crushed Tim Tams.
IN SEPERATE BOWL, WHISK milk, egg & vanilla extract together.
COMBINE dry and wet together. -
LADDLE, COOK (few minutes each side) & PLATE UP protein pancakes! -
Top away, with the remaining two Tim Tams and some fresh raspberries or choose own toppings!

PEANUT BUTTER PROTEIN COOKIES ğŸ˜‹
-
1 cup peanut butter 
2/3 coconut sugar
2 scoops VPA Premium Whey vanilla
2 eggs
-
Instructions:
Pre-heat over to 180 degrees
Line baking tray with paper.
Combine all ingredients and mix until consistency resembles cookie dough. (Texture may vary depending on the peanut butter used).
If it looks too dry, add more peanut butter, if its too liquidy add more protein powder).
Scoop 2 tbs worth of batter and roll with hands. May need to wet hands with a few drops of water to keep batter from sticking. 
Repeat with remaining dough, place them on the tray.  Use fork, press down gently on each cookie to create criss-cross marks.  If the fork sticks dip it in water as necessary. 
Transfer to oven and bake for 10-12 minutes, or until the edges of the cookies slightly start to turn brown.
-

.
.

What are EAA's?
Essential Amino Acids or EAA's are a group of 9 amino acids (lysine, histidine, isoleucine, leucine, methionine phenylalanine, tryptophan, valine and threonine). These amino acids are essential because they canâ€™t be made in the body and must come from food sources or supplements. These essential amino acids have been formulated at the perfect ratio to optimize your body for rapid muscle recovery.
-
Because of their simple form VPAs EAA's have the ability to digest into your bloodstream quickly and start working to repair and build muscles. If you are looking for faster recovery from intensive physical exercise, protect your muscles from catabolism, and wanting to fuel your muscles to get the most out of your training and physical performance than VPA EAA's are for you. *Complies with FSANZ.

What are EAA's anyway? I am so glad you asked ğŸ˜Š
-
Have you ever wanted to get fast muscle recovery after exercise, but didn't want to stomach a milky, dairy-based protein shake? This is where EAAs come in ğŸ˜
-
What are EAAs?
Essential Amino Acids or EAA's are a group of 9 amino acids (lysine, histidine, isoleucine, leucine, methionine phenylalanine, tryptophan, valine and threonine). These amino acids are essential because they canâ€™t be made in the body and must come from food sources or supplements. These essential amino acids have been formulated at the perfect ratio to optimize your body for rapid muscle recovery ğŸ’ª
-
Who are EAAs for?
Athletes undergoing intensive exercise and need rapid muscle recovery. EAA Capsules are perfect for endurance athletes who want to supply their muscles the building blocks to recover but donâ€™t want to have a milky protein shake. EAA Capsules are also perfect for individuals who are wanting to build muscle tissue and recover from heavy weight lifting quickly ğŸ’ª
.
.
.

Compare yourself to who you were yesterday, not to who someone else is today...
-
